findings.title: Check Optimization
findings.description: The contract contains duplicated code segments that check if the `transferAmount` is greater than zero, which are present in an if/else statement.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract updates variables even if its current state is the same as the one passed as an argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: Pair Address Validation
findings.description: The contract is missing address validation in the pair address argument, which can introduce security risks and potential attacks.

findings.title: Fixed Swap Address
findings.description: The swap address is assigned once and cannot be changed, which may prevent the contract from migrating to a new liquidity pool pair or decentralized exchange.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. The `immutable` is a special declaration for this kind of state variables that saves gas when it is defined.

findings.title: Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: In Solidity, dead code is code that is written in the contract, but is never executed or reached during normal contract execution.

findings.title: Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables that have been configured on user-supplied input. These variables are missing proper checks for the case where a value is zero, which can lead to problems when the contract is executed.

findings.title: Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
